title: In school, we always write things down (including notes, classwork, assessments, and homework), and writing is important for learning at school. Why is it vandalism to write on school walls? - Quora

response.answer_text: Oh, I bet you thought that was a clever question! Okay, I’ll play. Have you ever tried taking a wall into your class with you?Have you ever carried a wall home to study from?Don’t you find it inconvenient to write around all the things on the wall? Switches, pictures, mirrors, moulding, etc.?When you’ve filled both sides, what do you do? And where do you store the first one.There’s the possibility of painting the wall when you’ve finished the year or course and reusing it, so that’s a point for sustainability as long as you use water-based paint.Using a wall in class is also difficult as:You can’t write notes to friendsMake spitballsMake paper aeroplanes.While walls may last longer than paper, they get crumbly, and the surface isn’t particularly good for using a biro or a fountain pen. Painting out mistakes is easy, though.Some research would need to be done to see what walls are best to write on.cinder blocklime plasterwallboardbrickplaster on wood lathplaster on metal lathIn light of the above, how are you going to ensure that you’re writing on the best type of all.I think you’ll find that the disadvantages outweigh the advantages. They must do, otherwise what I read on walls wouldn’t be so sloppy, badly spelled or just illegible.

For the SECOND (it’s not TWO, it’s SECOND) time, IT IS VANDALISM to write ANYTHING on the school walls. School walls are the public school’s property AND they are NOT your property. Thus writing on school walls is considered DEFACING public school property and is considered property damage. Regardless of what you write and/or what you use to write on the school walls, it is STILL VANDALISM. Whether you wrote something good or bad on the school walls, and whether you wrote it in pencil or not, it is NOT OK. PERIOD. When you do your schoolwork -- like classwork, worksheets, quizzes, tests, homework, and taking notes -- do you EVER write your notes, work, answers, and ideas, or even your name and the date on the school walls? NO!!!! You always write them on paper or in your notebook, and NOT on the school walls!!!!! You do not write ANYTHING on school walls. If you want to write something, WRITE ON PAPER OR IN YOUR NOTEBOOK FOR GOODNESS’S SAKE. Paper and notebooks are yours to write on, but school walls are not. Regards, Aaron Chao

The school walls are not something that you take with you at the end of the day, writing on the walls usually requires an expenditure of paint and a worker to remove, and as painting a small area usually enhances the attention to that space (paints don't match due to fading) the entire wall needs to be painted. Due to allergies and space constraints this cannot be completed while school is in session so that writing has to remain until there is a break. Many don't realize that it is vandalism to write on any property that is not your own, it's just that building that are not currently occupied rarely find the culprit and prosecute while schools usually have cameras in the common areas and can discover the culprits without too much trouble. It is a crime and punishments can range from jail time to having to pay for repainting or having to actually repaint the area.

So let me break this down for you. Writing is important; I would argue the most important skill. It is often said, “Writing is thinking”. However, each example you provided is done on paper you purchased, and is for your eyes only. It also has a specific purpose in that it furthers your education. Did you buy that wall? No. Did you put what you wrote there for educational purposes or for self-expression? Did it cost money to remove what you wrote in notebook? No. If writing is thinking, what are you thinking with this logic? So, it is a case of vandalism and nuisance behavior over actual writing. Want to write on walls? Buy your own or become a muralist so people will pay you to write/express yourself in walls. Until then, keep your work in your folder.

Writing about educational topics and even school-appropriate creative writing is a wonderful thing. Writing on school walls is usually profane or otherwise inappropriate, and does nothing to stimulate the mind like taking notes or writing essays would. If it’s something inspiring, artistic, or would otherwise make the school a more positive place, either do it and be prepared to explain yourself or maybe even ask permission first! Admins are sometimes way nicer than they look, and if you can present a well-reasoned argument about why this particular wall decoration is not vandalism and how it could improve the school in some way, they might agree with you!

Because vandalism in the form of graffiti is destruction of school property. Destruction of public or private property is a crime that can't be rationalized away…
Because the walls don't belong to you. If the owner wanted that writing done, then it is legal!

When you go out to purchase school supplies — pencils, notebooks, software — do you buy and pay for school walls? (Hint: the answer is NO, because they do not belong to you and are permanent, not transitory, like paper.)
The walls are a good writing space but if everyone wrote on them, how could we read it? You should have some bulletin boards to post things.
